questions.answer_description:
* Creating a PDB
Rather than constructing the data dictionary tables that define an empty PDB from scratch, and then populating its Obj$ and Dependency$ tables, the empty PDB is created when the CDB is created. (Here, we use empty to mean containing no customer-created artifacts.) It is referred to as the seed PDB and has the name
PDB$Seed. Every CDB non-negotiably contains a seed PDB; it is non-negotiably always open in read-only mode. This has no conceptual significance; rather, it is just an optimization device. The create PDB operation is implemented as a special case of the clone PDB operation. The size of the seed PDB is only about 1 gigabyte and it takes only a few seconds on a typical machine to copy it.

choices.D: Alt existing PDBs must be closed.
choices.B: The CDB must be in the mount stage.
choices.C: The CDB must be in the nomount stage.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Tested that the PDB cannot be created in mount mode.

questions.question_text:
In your multitenant container database (CDB) with two pluggable database (PDBs). You want to create a new PDB by using SQL Developer.
Which statement is true?

discussion.content:
Answer BC
because the service name in tns file maybe isn't orcl

comments.content:
B,C is correct

A is incorrect. You CAN have tnsnames.ora configured on both the local and remote server. However, for the purpose of successful connection to the DB server, the client initiating the above command MUST have a tnsnames.ora file with the net service name being used (in this case orcl) on their server. The tnsnames.ora in the remote DB does NOT have to have the exact same tns entry for successful connection. The requirement is that the net service name be registered with the listener it is using to request connection to the DB server. So B is correct as opposed to A. 

C is correct. I believe the question means "register" when they reference define. In that case C is correct. The DB attempting a connection MUST be registered with the listener it will use to request connection to a DB server.

discussion.content:
AE
A. tnsname.ora should be configured on both host and clint
E. the service name orcl should be configured on tnsnames.ora
c not correct There is no service name parameter on listener file

questions.question_text:
Examine this command executed on a client that is remote from the database server.

SQL> CONNECT hr/hr@orcl -
Which two are required for this command to connect the SQLPLUS client to a database instance? (Choose two.)

choices.C: A service name must be defined to the listener that matches the service name in the orcl TNS entry
choices.E: The service name orcl must be defined to the listener
choices.A: An orcl TNS entry must be defined in the client-side and server-side tnsnames.ora files
choices.D: An orcl TNS entry must be defined in the server-side tnsnames.ora file
choices.B: An orcl TNS entry must be defined in the client-side tnsnames.ora file

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Answer is AD

questions.question_text: Which two must be installed or configured either manually or by DBCA in order to use Enterprise Manager Database Express (EM Express)? (Choose two.)

choices.B: The APEX_PUBLIC_USER role must be granted to SYSMAN
choices.C: A SYSMAN user with SYSDBA privilege must be created
choices.D: At least one TCP/IP dispatcher must be configured
choices.A: A port number for Oracle HTTP Server must be configured
choices.E: The Oracle HTTP Server must be installed

questions.question_text: Which four statements are true about database instance behavior? (Choose four.)

discussion.content: I check some dynamic views with nomount state and they are working.... Although in question is mention all dynamic views... Maybe B is correct

comments.content:
I agree with you about C. Interestingly enough, I think both A and C are wrong. When you get "connected to an idle instance" this means that your DB is not at least STARTED. The command startup nomount simply starts the database so it is not an idle instance. 

Either the correct question asks for only three correct answers, or the answer choices are written incorrectly in this dump (I have seen that is an occasional occurrence with this dump).

A is wrong:
after startup nomount, all memory structures are created, and basic background processes started (such as pmon). So the instance is not idle.

discussion.content: C is wrong. the consistency checking is in open process. ADEF is correct.

choices.C: The consistency of redo logs and data files is checked when mounting the database
choices.D: Redo log files can be renamed in MOUNT state
choices.F: Datafiles can be renamed in MOUNT state
choices.A: An idle instance is created when a STARTUP NOMOUNT is successful
choices.E: An SPFILE can be updated when connected to an idle instance
choices.B: All dynamic performance views (v$ views) return data when queried from a session connected to an instance in NOMOUNT state

choices.C: A SPFILE can be created by an idle instance
choices.A: SPFILEs and PFILEs may both be edited with an O/S editing utility
choices.B: Some SPFILE parameters can be modified successfully with the SCOPE=MEMORY clause
choices.E: All SPFILE parameters can be modified successfully with the SCOPE=BOTH clause
choices.D: A PFILE can be created by an idle instance
choices.F: All SPFILE parameters can be modified successfully with the SCOPE=MEMORY clause

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
The answer is BCD

BCD is corret.

E - wrong:

SCOPE = BOTH: The ALTER SYSTEM change is applied in both the server parameter file and memory. No static parameter change is allowed.

BDE is correct
spfile change default scope = both
